messages.message:
Hi- I know this is an open feature request already but wanted to reiterate as it came up on a call with The Hartford, in addition to AXIS Capital (both multi-billion commercial insurance carriers): The ability to analyze a new business submission or an insurance policy against a repository of data (ex. underwriting guidelines, best practices etc). @avi

The sooner we can start demoing this the better.

being able to interrogate the submission package against underwriting policy and guidelines helps *Rank and prioriritize* the submission (ex. is the umbrella coverage within our risk tolerance based on the other underlying attributes of the submission)
GenAI would potentially shortcut the need to extract 120+ data elements

Thanks, great to get more customer signal. Few related tickets on this.
• [EPD-1715] Upload doc to query multidoc knowledgebase - Jira (atlassian.net (http://atlassian.net)) (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-1715) - base tech for demos
• [EPD-1853] Create converse and chatbots component for IDP integration - Jira (atlassian.net (http://atlassian.net)) (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-1853)

@Will Brown do you have an impression of whether the workflow would be.
1. Underwriter sees extraction result, then asks follow up guidelines queries - eg: my claim has a property in Iran? Am I allowed to underwrite it?
2. OR/AND Underwriter sees extraction result, including an auto-computed field which returns a ~free-form response about whether the submission meets their guidelines? _[likely more challenging]_
We're tracking for 1 but 2 seems more like a solid productivity improvement. Would 1 be sufficient to land demos and get things moving? cc: @Bastiane
More like 2, starting with summary of the submission and then ultimately marrying that with context of underwriting guidelines.

Michael took some notes from the disco today
• “underwriting summarization, risk evaluation, analyze against knowledge repo to provide insight into how the submission matches up and any flags”
    ◦ *Example Flag Converse would come up with:* “The submission is asking for $10MM umbrella limit but in this sector The Hartford only allows $5MM”

So you’d want to take all that submission data — company size, industry, risk stripe (what do they want insured) and more (there are typically 120+ different key datapoints from a mid market commercial submission)
and compare against the knowledge base (ex. underwriting guidelines) to rank the submission — ultimately trying to answer the question, “how likely are we to underwrite the submission as is?”
Then all the ones with high likelihood get bumped to the top of the pile

Right now, The Hartford is doing what AXA tried to do with IB initially. That is - use deep learning to extract ALL the submission data, and then run it through 3 layers of business logic. In order to automate the ranking process, you have to extract all 120 datapoints with high raw accuracy and confidence (unlikely) AND pass all the business logic without failing.

So the prospect estimated they get about 20% automation out of the submission ranking solution today. And a lot of that comes ONLY from Workers Comp which is the simplest to automate. So really there is barely any business value from this solution.

What excites me about ultimate promise of GenAI here — you eliminate the need to extract all the datapoints and build all the business logic layers. Or you can do both.

Got it, very useful input. I'm wondering if we take this step-wise. Use #1 to win demo+POCs, then use #2 for the deployment CUJ? The tech of doing the actual submission <-> guidelines review would land with #1 itself
